message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the systolic murmur along the left sternal border, suggests that the patient may have a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect. Prostaglandin E1 is used to keep the ductus arteriosus open until surgical correction can be performed, thus it is the most likely effective treatment for this patient's condition. Leukotriene E4 and Prostaglandin E2 and I2 are not used in the treatment of congenital heart defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms listed suggest a congenital heart defect, likely ductal-dependent coarctation of the aorta (indicated by diminished lower extremity pulses and the need for prostaglandins). Among the options, only Prostaglandin E1 can help maintain patency of the ductus arteriosus and improve blood flow to the lower extremities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest a duct-dependent congenital heart disease, specifically a coarctation of the aorta. Prostaglandin E1 can help keep the ductus arteriosus patent, allowing for shunting of blood to the descending aorta to provide blood flow to the lower extremities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest a congenital heart defect, specifically a duct-dependent lesion. Prostaglandin E1 is used to maintain ductal patency in newborns with duct-dependent lesions, allowing for adequate oxygenation until definitive treatment can be performed. The other options are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including rapid breathing, irritability, cold feet, and diminished pulses, suggest a possible congenital heart disease, specifically ductal-dependent circulation. Prostaglandin E1 can help maintain patency of ductus arteriosus, which can improve blood flow and oxygenation. None of the other options are used to treat ductal-dependent circulation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and cardiac auscultation suggest a congenital heart defect, specifically coarctation of the aorta. Prostaglandin E1 helps to keep the ductus arteriosus open, which can improve blood flow to the lower extremities and relieve symptoms. Leukotriene E4 and Prostaglandin E2 and I2 are not used to treat this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect, which means that the patient relies on the ductus arteriosus for systemic blood flow. Prostaglandin E1 helps keep the ductus arteriosus open, providing systemic blood flow.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and clinical findings suggest a congenital heart defect with possible interruption of blood flow to the lower extremities. Prostaglandin E1 is used to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus until corrective surgery can be performed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, particularly the harsh systolic murmur along the left sternal border, suggest congenital heart disease. Prostaglandin E1 is used to treat congenital heart disease by keeping the ductus arteriosus open to facilitate blood flow to the lungs. Leukotriene E4 is not used to treat congenital heart disease, while Prostaglandin E2 and I2 are not used as a first-line treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a congenital heart disease with decreased pulmonary blood flow, such as Tetralogy of Fallot. Prostaglandin E1 can maintain patency of the ductus arteriosus, which increases blood flow to the lungs and improves symptoms. Leukotriene E4 and Prostaglandin E2 and I2 are not indicated for this specific condition.
